[[HighTone Records|HighTone]] | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Cornelius Green''' (December 12, 1928 – April 23, 1995), known professionally as '''Lonesome Sundown''', was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[musician]], best known for his [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] for [[Excello Records]] in the 1950s and early 1960s. ==Biography== Green was born on the Dugas Plantation near [[Donaldsonville, Louisiana|Donaldsonville]], [[Louisiana]].{{cite book |first= |last= |url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=s9PeKHhZIK4C&pg=PA134&lpg=PA134&dq=sundown+%22cornelius+green%22+miller&source=bl&ots=WQHzKZEgNF&sig=71V1wUqEQxakcEQ2jfzTJlxOoWg&hl=en&ei=qBo7S7STHJmy0gTmuKmSBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CBUQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=sundown%20%22cornelius%20green%22%20miller&f=false|title=South to Louisiana: The Music of the Cajun Bayous|author=John Broven |publisher=|accessdate=December 30, 2009}} At the age of 18, he moved to [[New Orleans]] and worked in various jobs including as a porter at the New Southport Club, a [[casino]] in [[Jefferson Parish, Louisiana|Jefferson Parish]]. He returned to Donaldsonville by 1948 and, inspired by [[Muddy Waters]] and [[John Lee Hooker]], began taking guitar lessons from a cousin. In 1953, after a brief period as a truck driver in [[Jeanerette, Louisiana]], he moved again to work at the Gulf Oil Refinery in [[Port Arthur, Texas]]. By this time he had begun to take his music more seriously, jamming at local clubs, and in 1955 was invited by [[Clifton Chenier]] to sit in with his new band, the Zydeco Ramblers, at the Blue Moon Club in [[Lake Charles, Louisiana|Lake Charles]]. Chenier offered him the post of second guitarist in the band, alongside first guitarist [[Phillip Walker]]. Green toured with them as far as [[Chicago]] and [[Los Angeles]], where Chenier's recording of "The Cat's Dreaming" was inspired by Green falling asleep during a session, and where Green auditioned for producer [[Bumps Blackwell]] but failed to get a contract.{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lonesome-sundown-mn0000830718/biography |title=Lonesome Sundown | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://www.offbeat.com/2003/09/01/cornelius-green-lonesome-sundown/|title=Masters of Louisiana Music: Cornelius Green "Lonesome Sundown" by Jeff Hannusch |publisher=Offbeat.com |accessdate=November 23, 2009}}{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 138 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} Green married later in 1955, left the Zydeco Ramblers, and moved to [[Opelousas, Louisiana]] where he began playing with Lloyd Reynauld and writing his own material. He recorded a [[demo (music)|demo]] tape, and took it to producer [[J. D. "Jay" Miller]] in [[Crowley, Louisiana|Crowley]]. Miller was impressed, gave the singer/ guitarist the [[stage name]] "Lonesome Sundown", and recorded his debut [[single (music)|single]], "Leave My Money Alone" b/w "Lost Without Love", which he leased to Excello Records in 1956. The follow-up, "Lonesome Whistler" b/w "My Home Is A Prison", was more successful, and Sundown became one of Miller's south Louisiana stable of musicians. Although he never had a [[record chart|chart]] [[hit record|hit]], he recorded for Miller for eight years, and his records sold in respectable quantities, his output including "Don’t Say A Word" (featuring [[Lazy Lester]] on [[harmonica]]), "I'm a Mojo Man," "You Know I Love You," "I Stood By (And Watched Another Man Steal My Gal)," "My Home Ain't Here," and the much [[cover version|covered]], "Gonna Stick To You Baby." Unusually for Louisiana musicians, Sundown's style of the [[blues]] was more in keeping with the sound of Muddy Waters than that of [[Jimmy Reed]], and his sombre and melancholic recordings and instantly recognizable style were described by Miller as "the sound of the swamp". Sundown continued to work with Miller into the early 1960s, and in 1964 recorded "Hoo Doo Woman Blues" b/w "I’ve Got A Broken Heart", recordings which have been described as among "the last ethnic down-home blues [[45 (record)|45]]s aimed exclusively at the Negro market". However, by 1965 Sundown had become disillusioned with his lack of success, experienced a traumatic divorce, retired from the [[music industry]] to work as a laborer, and joined the Lord Jesus Christ of the Apostolic Faith Fellowship Throughout the World Church, where he eventually became a minister. He was persuaded back to the [[recording studio]]s in 1977, and recorded another blues [[album]], ''Been Gone Too Long'', co-produced by [[Bruce Bromberg]] and Dennis Walker, originally for Joliet Records. Despite its quality, disappointing sales ensued, even after being reissued on [[Alligator Records|Alligator]]. His final single release was 1977's "I Betcha".{{cite web|url=http://koti.mbnet.fi/wdd/lonesomesundown.htm |title=WangDangDula.com |publisher=Koti.mbnet.fi |date=2010-12-24 |accessdate=2014-01-27}} Sundown did several [[concert]]s, including an appearance at the 1979 [[New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival]], and tours of [[Sweden]] and [[Japan]] with Phillip Walker, but then walked away from the music business for good. In 1994 he suffered a [[stroke]], and he was no longer able to speak. Sundown died in [[Gonzales, Louisiana]], in April 1995, aged 66.{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1995.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1994 - 1995 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} He was posthumously inducted into the Louisiana Blues Hall of Fame in 2000. ==Selected discography== *''Lonesome Lonely Blues'' (1970) - Excello *''Been Gone Too Long'' (1977) - [[HighTone Records|HighTone]]{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lonesome-sundown-mn0000830718/discography |title=Lonesome Sundown | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} ==See also== *[[List of swamp blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p433/biography|pure_url=yes}} Biography at Allmusic.com] *[http://koti.mbnet.fi/wdd/lonesomesundown.htm Full discography at Koti.mbnet.fi] {{Authority control|VIAF=24145796}} {{Persondata | NAME = Cornelius Green | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Lonesome Sundown | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[musician]] | DATE OF BIRTH = December 12, 1928 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Donaldsonville, Louisiana]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = April 23, 1995 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Gonzales, Louisiana]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lonesome Sundown}} [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:People from Ascension Parish, Louisiana]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:Swamp blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:Louisiana blues musicians]] [[Category:Songwriters from Louisiana]]
